Award.AwardTitle: Career Pathways in Construction, Architectural Engineering, and Design Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Seminole State College of Florida (SSC) partnering with the local school district and industry plans to enhance and expand viable STEM academic pathways in the AS degree fields of building construction technology, architectural engineering technology, architectural design, and drafting and design technology. Project activities include: (1) reaching out to the high school level to supplement current secondary instruction with enhanced postsecondary academic planning and learning opportunities of increased rigor; (2) strengthening the current articulated and seamless system of multiple education and career entry and exit points designed to maximize the number of students who complete a STEM-related associate degree (or higher) to facilitate economic development; and (3) establishing new research-based intervention strategies to facilitate postsecondary student retention and completion. In addition, as part of a broader curriculum enhancement effort, SSC targets the formal integration of Green and Sustainable Design concepts into the curriculum. The goal is to increase the enrollment, retention and graduation rate of students in the aforementioned fields. The project objectives and activities are based on existing research and data.

The outcomes of this project contribute to the body of knowledge on technician education and address factors that impact lower division student success and high school-community college-university collaboration. The impacts of the project also include increasing the participation of underrepresented groups and creating a model that can be emulated by other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What are the major goals of the grant?

Work in collaboration with Seminole County Public Schools, is uniquely positioned to utilize ATE funds to provide a much-needed ray of opportunity to many underrepresented students who express an interest in pursuing Construction, Architecture/Engineering, and Design Technology degrees and careers, but may need: (1) additional motivators during high school to recognize that they have the skills to succeed; plus (2) additional academic support at the start of their postsecondary studies. SSC will establish a multi-level system of interventions, with an emphasis on learning experiences at the high school and lower division levels, to increase the number and diversity of students who are better prepared to pursue Construction, Architecture/Engineering, and Design Technology pathways through an articulated sequence of courses and programs up to the Master’s level.

 

 Specific objectives:

 Develop and incorporate project based learning into the targeted programs as a means of enhancing program quality as well as increasing enrollment and retention. 

 Significant Results:

Projects Completed as part of the extension year.  We developed significant Project Based Learning (PBL) projects within the targeted programs as part of a strategy to recruit, retain and complete more students but to also provide continuity from high school dual enrollment to college, provide more hands-on experiences and to enhance the quality of our programs.

We strongly believe that students should, from Day 1, begin learning how to create design solutions to increasingly complex problems.  Traditional program labs focus on single, narrow defined technical skill.  We have and continue to develop labs that focus on cross-disciplinary skills that require a whole device, system, or product design solution. 

Typically, students are not exposed to cross-disciplinary design solution exercises until the end of their academic career in a single capstone course.  We strive to incorporate these exercises throughout the program, with one design/build/test/refine project, of increasing complexity each year.  Examples of cross-disciplinary, project-based learning we have implemented in our programs include:

Tiny House Design:  Funded by the National Science Foundation grant, the students were given the project to design and then build a tiny house made popular by Jay Shafer.  These tiny homes are ultra-affordable micro homes ranging from 100 to 400 s.f.  Our challenge to the student team was to add alternative energy systems to deliver a net-zero home.  This has become a wildly popular cross-disciplinary project for our engineering, design, and construction students.  The concept is to have the students design, build, and then sell one of these tiny homes each year to sustain the activities of the NSF grant beyond the funding term.

 

Design/Build and Test Pneumatic T-Shirt Launcher:  High school students in one of our introductory dual enrollment engineering courses worked in teams to design, build, and test a T-shirt launcher capable of delivering T?shirts from the Amway arena floor to the upper most decks (This is a humorous story in that a group of about 40 high school students identified this issue as a social injustice they wanted to solve.  Many of them have attended Orlando Magic basketball games in the new Amway Arena.  However, they could only afford the nosebleed seats in the upper decks and the T-shirt launchers used during timeouts and halftime cannot deliver T-shirts to the upper deck!).  The pneumatic devices are a great way to apply introductory physics and mathematics to solve a problem.  The students modeled the air as an ideal gas with adiabatic expansion, calibrated the model and then designed the size of the air chamber, pressure, length of barrel.  The students then tested the final device for velocity and distance. 

Design/Build and Test Quadcopter Drone:  Students design, build, and test a quadcopter drone to deliver pizza on campus.  This project made its debut during our second summer intensive program.   Ideal for incorporating a hands-on exercise in our mechatronics track integrating mechanical systems and electrical controls.

 

Converting a Chevy Cavalier to a Fully Electric Car:  Freshmen and sophomores completely rebuilt and transformed this car to fully electric, road-worthy standards.  Again, this project has become a showpiece for the program. 

Giving students increasingly complex projects, such as those mentioned above, throughout their program, enables graduates to be as skilled in the art of design as they are in all the component technical skills – across engineering disciplines. 

We have designed these programs so that, from the very first course, students are introduced to the skills and teamwork necessary to succeed in engineering practice.  They are immediately introduced to the applied nature of engineering.  These skills are taught by exposing them to the design process with open-ended problem-solving exercises requiring decision analysis and technical communications in a team environment.  The problems themselves are student-centered but real world problems such as developing green, sustainable and affordable housing and developing a fast and efficient way to deliver pizza across campus.


Last Modified: 09/29/2016
Modified by: Michael Staley

Converting a Chevy Cavalier to a Fully Electric Car: Freshmen and sophomores completely rebuilt and transformed this car to fully electric, road-worthy standards.
